tasks: Numerical approximation of high-dimensional McKean–Vlasov SDEs
results: Computational cost grows at most polynomially in the dimension and the reciprocal of the prescribed error tolerance
title: Multilevel Picard Approximations for McKean-Vlasov Stochastic Differential Equations with Nonconstan.pdf
abstract: . We introduce multilevel Picard (MLP) approximations for McKean–Vlasov stochastic diﬀerential equations (SDEs) with nonconstant diﬀusion coeﬃcient. Under standard Lipschitz assumptions on the coeﬃcients, we show that the MLP algorithm approximates the solution of the SDE in the L2-sense without the curse of dimensionality. The latter means that its computational cost grows at most polynomially in both the dimension and the reciprocal of the prescribed error tolerance. In two numerical experiments, we demonstrate its applicability by approximating McKean–Vlasov SDEs in dimensions up to 10000. 1. Introduction McKean–Vlasov stochastic diﬀerential equations (SDEs) provide a mathematical framework to analyze the limiting behavior of stochastic systems of weakly interacting particles. In order to describe the limit, these SDEs do not only depend on the state of the process but also on their distribution, and are therefore also referred to as distribution-dependent SDEs or mean- ﬁeld SDEs in the literature. First introduced by McKean in [43] to model the Vlasov equation, these equations have since found applications in various ﬁelds, including statistical physics (see, e.g., [10,23,39,60]), mathematical biology (see, e.g., [4,13,30,45,48]), social sciences (see, e.g., [14, 19,29]), mean-ﬁeld games (see, e.g., [15,16,17]), stochastic control (see, e.g., [12]), mathematical ﬁnance (see, e.g., [28]), and the analysis of neural networks (see, e.g., [34,46,57,58]). More precisely, for d ∈ N and terminal time T > 0, we consider McKean–Vlasov SDEs deﬁned for every t ∈[0, T] by Xd ∞(t) = ξd + Z t 0 E  µd(x, Xd ∞(s))  |x=Xd∞(s) ds + Z t 0 E  σd(x, Xd ∞(s))  |x=Xd∞(s) dW d(s), (1) with initial value ξd ∈ Rd, where µd : Rd × Rd → Rd and σd : Rd × Rd → Rd×d are suﬃciently regular functions, and where W d = (W d(t))t∈[0,T] is a d-dimensional standard Brownian motion. The solution of (1) can be seen as limit of weakly interacting particles (X d,n N )n=1,...,N, as N →∞, where each particle X d,n N := (X d,n N (t))t∈[0,T] satisﬁes the SDE deﬁned for every t ∈[0, T] by X d,n N (t) = ξd + 1 N N X m=1 Z t 0 µd(X d,n N (s), X d,m N (s))ds + 1 N N X m=1 Z t 0 σd(X d,n N (s), X d,m N (s))dW d(s). This phenomena is called propagation of chaos and was studied in [31,39,41,44,60]. While exis- tence and uniqueness of (1) have been established in [32,47,56,60], the numerical approximation of (1) has been considered in, e.g., [2,5,6,7,9,11,20,21,22,24,25,40,42,52,53,54,55,61,62]. In this paper, we are interested in the numerical approximation of high-dimensional McK- ean–Vlasov SDEs. Our contribution is twofold: We introduce a multilevel Picard (MLP) approx- imation of (1) and show that it overcomes the curse of dimensionality when approximating (1) in the L2-sense. The latter means that the computational cost of the MLP algorithm grow at most polynomially in the space dimension d of the SDE (1) and the reciprocal ǫ−1 of the prescribed 2020 Mathematics Subject Classiﬁcation. 60H10, 60H35, 65C05, 65C30. Key words and phrases. McKean–Vlasov SDE, distribution-dependent SDE, mean-ﬁeld SDE, high-dimensional SDE, multilevel Picard approximation, curse of dimensionality.
